p:
One of the most obvious effects of climate change on biodiversity is the projected change in species geographical ranges
15, 16 . The geographic distribution of any species, with some degrees of disequilibrium, is a spatial representation of its ‘ ecological niche’. Extrinsic factors such as abiotic conditions and species interactions, and intrinsic ones such as dispersal capability and genetic plasticity determine form, dynamic, and evolution of the niche
17 . The interactions between these factors through past evolutionary time-scales determine the current distribution range of the species
18 . In the Anthropocene, the rapid rate of climate change has caused signatures of range loss and range shift in many species, with an observed time lag of population dynamic responses relative to climatic trends
8 . Over the past century, increasing evidence of climate change impacts on biodiversity patterns has been documenting a globally consistent rate of poleward or upward shifts in many species’ geographic distributions
6, 7, 12, 15 , although some species show deviating responses
19, 20 .
